subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Find a basis for the subspace V = {(1, 0), (0, 1)} in ℝ².
hints: A basis is a set of vectors that span the subspace and are linearly independent.
You can start by finding two linearly independent vectors in V.
Then, check if these vectors form a spanning set for V.
solutionHtml:
To find a basis, we first observe that {(1, 0), (0, 1)} are linearly independent.

We can verify this by checking the determinant:

\[\det \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = 1 \neq 0.\]

Next, we show that {(1, 0), (0, 1)} span V.

We can write any vector in V as a linear combination of the basis vectors:

\[c_1(1, 0) + c_2(0, 1) = (c_1, c_2).\]

This shows that {(1, 0), (0, 1)} is a basis for V.

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml:
Find a basis for the subspace spanned by the vectors \(\mathbf{v}_1 = (1, 2), \mathbf{v}_2 = (3, -1)\) in \(\mathbb{R}^2\).

",
hints:
[ "

Think about what it means for a set of vectors to span a subspace.

", "

You can use the standard basis \((1, 0), (0, 1)\) as a starting point.

", "

Try to find a combination of \(\mathbf{v}_1\) and \(\mathbf{v}_2\) that equals one of the standard basis vectors.

" ],
solutionHtml:
To find a basis, we can start by writing down all possible linear combinations of \(\mathbf{v}_1\) and \(\mathbf{v}_2\):

  • \(\mathbf{0} = c_1 \mathbf{v}_1 + c_2 \mathbf{v}_2\)

Substituting in the values of \(\mathbf{v}_1\) and \(\mathbf{v}_2\), we get:

  • \((c_1, 2c_1 + c_2) = (0, 0)\)

This is equivalent to the system:

  • \(c_1 = 0\)
  • \(2c_1 + c_2 = 0\)

Solving this system, we find that \(c_1 = 0\) and \(c_2 = 0\), so \(\mathbf{v}_1 = (1, 2)\) is a basis vector.

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml:
Find a basis for the subspace of ℝ² spanned by \(\begin{bmatrix}1\\2\end{bmatrix}\) and \(\begin{bmatrix}3\\4\end{bmatrix}\).

",
hints: Use the span property to find a basis for the subspace.
Check that your basis is linearly independent and spans the subspace.
solutionHtml:
To find a basis, we start with the standard basis \(\{\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\}\). We then use the span property to see that

\(\begin{bmatrix}1\\2\end{bmatrix}\) = 1⋅\(\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}\) + 2⋅\(\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\),

\(\begin{bmatrix}3\\4\end{bmatrix}\) = 3⋅\(\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}\) + 4⋅\(\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\).

This shows that the standard basis spans the subspace, so it is a basis.

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Find a basis for the subspace \mathbb{W} = \{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^3 : x_1 + 2x_2 - x_3 = 0\}.",
hints: Check if you can find a basis by inspection.
If not, try to find two linearly independent vectors in \mathbb{W}.
Use the fact that any subspace is spanned by its basis.
solutionHtml:
To find a basis for \\mathbb{W}, first notice that \mathbf{x}_1 = (1, 0, -2) and \\mathbf{x}_2 = (2, 1, 0) are both in \\mathbb{W}. Since they're linearly independent, we can take them as a basis.

We can verify that any vector in \\mathbb{W} is spanned by these two vectors:

\mathbf{x} = (x_1, x_2, x_3) \in \\mathbb{W} \Rightarrow x_1 + 2x_2 - x_3 = 0

\\Rightarrow \\mathbf{x} = c_1 \\mathbf{x}_1 + c_2 \\mathbf{x}_2, c_1, c_2 \in \\mathbb{R}.

",
answerShort: A basis for \\mathbb{W} is \\{\mathbf{x}_1, \\mathbf{x}_2\}" },
